  • 3–4 kaffir lime leaves, torn
  • 3 slices galangal
  • 2–3 Thai chilies, smashed (adjust to taste)
  • 200 g (7 oz) mushrooms, halved or sliced
  • 2–3 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for vegetarian)
  • 1–2 tbsp lime juice (to taste)
  • 1–2 tsp sugar (optional)
  • Fresh cilantro for garnish

Instructions

  1. Prepare stock: Bring chicken or vegetable stock to a boil in a pot.
  2. Add aromatics: Add lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, galangal, and Thai chilies. Simmer 5–10 minutes to infuse flavors.
  3. Add mushrooms: Add mushrooms and simmer for 2–3 minutes until slightly tender.
  4. Add shrimp: Add shrimp and cook 2–3 minutes until pink and cooked through.
  5. Season: Add fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar (if using). Adjust balance of sour, salty, and sweet according to taste.
  6. Serve: Remove lemongrass, galangal, and lime leaves. Ladle soup into bowls, garnish with fresh cilantro, and serve hot.

Tips & Variations

  • Adjust chili to control spiciness.
  • For a creamy version, add 1/2 cup coconut milk at the end.
  • Vegetarian version: Replace shrimp with tofu or extra mushrooms and use soy sauce instead of fish sauce.
  • Use fresh herbs for authentic fragrance; dried herbs won’t give the same depth of flavor.

name: Green Curry
recipe:
Thai Green Curry

Thai Green Curry is a fragrant and spicy curry made with green curry paste, coconut milk, vegetables, and protein such as chicken, tofu, or shrimp. It is aromatic, creamy, and balanced with sweet, salty, and spicy flavors.

Ingredients (serves 3–4)

  • 400 g (14 oz) chicken, tofu, or shrimp
  • 2–3 tbsp green curry paste
  • 2 cups (480 ml) coconut milk
  • 1 cup mixed vegetables (bell peppers, zucchini, bamboo shoots, or eggplant)
  • 2–3 kaffir lime leaves, torn
  • 1–2 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for vegetarian)
  • 1–2 tsp sugar
  • 1 tbsp vegetable oil
  • Fresh Thai basil or cilantro for garnish

Instructions

  1. Heat oil: In a pan or wok, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add green curry paste and sauté for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
  2. Add coconut milk: Pour in half of the coconut milk, stirring to combine with curry paste. Simmer 2–3 minutes.
  3. Add protein: Add chicken, tofu, or shrimp and cook until nearly done (chicken fully cooked, shrimp pink, tofu heated).
  4. Add vegetables: Stir in vegetables and remaining coconut milk. Simmer 5–7 minutes until vegetables are tender but crisp.
  5. Season: Add fish sauce (or soy sauce) and sugar to taste. Adjust seasoning to balance spicy, salty, and sweet flavors.
  6. Finish: Remove from heat, stir in torn kaffir lime leaves, and garnish with fresh Thai basil or cilantro.
  7. Serve: Serve hot with steamed jasmine rice.

Tips & Variations

  • Adjust curry paste quantity to control spiciness.
  • Vegetarian version: Use tofu and vegetable stock instead of meat and fish sauce.
  • For extra flavor, add a splash of lime juice or a few slices of fresh chili.
  • Other vegetables: peas, carrots, or baby corn can also be used.

name: Som Tum (Papaya Salad)
recipe:
Som Tum (Papaya Salad)

Som Tum is a vibrant Thai salad made from shredded green papaya, fresh vegetables, chilies, and a tangy, sweet, and spicy dressing. It’s crunchy, refreshing, and full of flavor.

Ingredients (serves 2–3)

  • 2 cups shredded green papaya
  • 1–2 cloves garlic
  • 1–2 Thai chilies (adjust to taste)
  • 10 cherry tomatoes, halved
  • 1/2 cup green beans, cut into 1-inch pieces
  • 2 tbsp roasted peanuts
  • 2 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for vegetarian)
  • 1–2 tbsp lime juice
  • 1–2 tsp palm sugar (or brown sugar)
  • Optional: dried shrimp or crab for added flavor

Instructions

  1. Pound aromatics: In a mortar and pestle, pound garlic and chilies until roughly crushed.
  2. Add sugar & sauce: Add palm sugar, fish sauce, and lime juice. Lightly pound to combine.
  3. Add vegetables: Add green beans and cherry tomatoes. Lightly bruise them with the pestle to release flavor.
  4. Add papaya: Add shredded papaya and toss gently with the dressing until evenly coated.
  5. Add peanuts: Stir in roasted peanuts (and dried shrimp/crab if using).
  6. Serve: Transfer to a plate and serve immediately as a refreshing starter or side dish.

Tips & Variations

  • Adjust chilies to control spiciness.
  • Use a kitchen knife or salad tongs if you don’t have a mortar and pestle; just mix ingredients thoroughly.
  • For a vegetarian version, omit fish sauce or use soy sauce.
  • Other vegetables: shredded carrots, bell peppers, or cucumber can be added for extra color and crunch.

name: Massaman Curry
recipe:
Massaman Curry

Massaman Curry is a rich and mildly spiced Thai curry with influences from Indian cuisine. Made with coconut milk, tender meat or tofu, potatoes, peanuts, and aromatic spices, it’s sweet, savory, and slightly nutty.

Ingredients (serves 3–4)

  • 400 g (14 oz) chicken, beef, or tofu
  • 2–3 tbsp Massaman curry paste
  • 2 cups (480 ml) coconut milk
  • 2 medium potatoes, peeled and cubed
  • 1 onion, sliced
  • 2–3 tbsp roasted peanuts
  • 1–2 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for vegetarian)
  • 1–2 tbsp palm sugar
  • 1–2 tbsp tamarind paste (optional, for tanginess)
  • 1 cinnamon stick
  • 2–3 cardamom pods (optional)
  • 1 tbsp vegetable oil
  • Fresh cilantro or Thai basil for garnish

Instructions

  1. Heat oil: In a pan or wok, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add Massaman curry paste and sauté 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
  2. Add coconut milk: Pour in half of the coconut milk and stir to combine with curry paste. Simmer for 2–3 minutes.
  3. Add protein: Add chicken, beef, or tofu. Cook until partially done.
  4. Add vegetables & spices: Add potatoes, onion, cinnamon stick, and cardamom pods. Pour in remaining coconut milk, simmer 20–25 minutes until meat is tender and potatoes are cooked through.
  5. Season: Add fish sauce (or soy sauce), palm sugar, and tamarind paste (if using). Taste and adjust seasoning for balance.
  6. Finish: Stir in roasted peanuts. Remove cinnamon stick and cardamom pods before serving.
  7. Serve: Garnish with fresh cilantro or Thai basil. Serve hot with steamed jasmine rice.

Tips & Variations

  • Adjust curry paste to control spiciness.
  • Vegetarian version: use tofu and vegetable stock instead of meat and fish sauce.
  • Other vegetables: carrots, sweet potatoes, or bell peppers can be added for variation.
  • Massaman curry is even better the next day as flavors deepen.

name: Pad See Ew
recipe:
Pad See Ew

Pad See Ew is a popular Thai stir-fried noodle dish made with wide rice noodles, soy sauce, garlic, Chinese broccoli, and your choice of protein. It’s savory, slightly sweet, and has a smoky wok flavor.

Ingredients (serves 2–3)

  • 200 g (7 oz) wide rice noodles, soaked or fresh
  • 200 g chicken, beef, pork, tofu, or shrimp
  • 2–3 cloves garlic, minced
  • 2 cups Chinese broccoli (gai lan), cut into 2-inch pieces
  • 2 eggs, lightly beaten
  • 2–3 tbsp light soy sauce
  • 1–2 tbsp dark soy sauce
  • 1 tsp sugar
  • 2 tbsp vegetable oil
  • Optional: white pepper to taste

Instructions

  1. Prepare noodles: Soak dried rice noodles in warm water until pliable, or use fresh noodles. Drain and set aside.
  2. Cook protein: Heat 1 tbsp oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Stir-fry protein until cooked through. Remove and set aside.
  3. Aromatics: Add remaining oil and sauté garlic until fragrant (do not burn).
  4. Egg: Push garlic to the side and pour in beaten eggs. Scramble briefly until just set.
  5. Noodles & sauce: Add noodles, light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, and sugar. Stir-fry, ensuring noodles are coated evenly. Adjust seasoning as needed.
  6. Add vegetables & protein: Add Chinese broccoli and cooked protein. Toss and stir-fry 2–3 minutes until broccoli is tender-crisp and everything is combined.
  7. Finish: Optional sprinkle of white pepper. Serve hot immediately.

Tips & Variations

  • Use high heat and a well-seasoned wok for best smoky flavor.
  • Adjust soy sauce levels for desired saltiness and color.
  • Other vegetables like carrots, bell peppers, or cabbage can be added.
  • For a vegetarian version, use tofu and soy sauce instead of meat and fish sauce.

name: Thai Basil Chicken
recipe:
Thai Basil Chicken (Pad Krapow Gai)

Thai Basil Chicken is a quick and flavorful stir-fry featuring minced chicken, garlic, chilies, and fragrant Thai basil. It’s savory, spicy, and perfect with steamed rice or a fried egg on top.

Ingredients (serves 2–3)

  • 400 g (14 oz) minced chicken
  • 4–5 cloves garlic, minced
  • 2–3 Thai chilies, chopped (adjust to taste)
  • 1 small onion, sliced (optional)
  • 1–2 tbsp vegetable oil
  • 2 tbsp light soy sauce
  • 1 tbsp fish sauce
  • 1 tsp sugar
  • 1 cup fresh Thai basil leaves

Instructions

  1. Prepare aromatics: Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add garlic and chilies, stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds).
  2. Cook chicken: Add minced chicken, breaking it up with a spatula. Stir-fry until fully cooked and lightly browned.
  3. Season: Add light soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar. Stir well to coat chicken evenly with the sauce.
  4. Add onion: If using, add sliced onion and stir-fry 1–2 minutes until slightly softened.
  5. Add basil: Turn off heat, add Thai basil leaves, and toss until wilted and fragrant.
  6. Serve: Serve immediately with steamed jasmine rice. Optionally, top with a fried egg for an authentic touch.

Tips & Variations

  • Adjust chilies to control spiciness.
  • For a vegetarian version, use tofu and soy sauce instead of chicken and fish sauce.
  • Other proteins like pork, beef, or shrimp can be substituted.
  • Use fresh Thai basil for authentic flavor; sweet basil won’t give the same aroma.

name: Mango Sticky Rice
recipe:
Thai Mango Sticky Rice (Khao Niew Mamuang)

Mango Sticky Rice is a beloved Thai dessert made with sweet sticky rice, creamy coconut sauce, and ripe mangoes. It’s rich, fragrant, and perfectly balanced between sweet and salty flavors.

Ingredients (serves 3–4)

  • 1 cup glutinous (sticky) rice
  • 1 1/2 cups coconut milk
  • 1/2 cup sugar
  • 1/2 tsp salt
  • 2 ripe mangoes, peeled and sliced
  • 1 tbsp toasted sesame seeds or mung beans (for garnish)

Instructions

  1. Prepare sticky rice: Soak sticky rice in water for at least 4 hours (or overnight). Drain, then steam for 20–25 minutes until tender and sticky.
  2. Make coconut sauce: In a saucepan, heat coconut milk with sugar and salt over low heat until dissolved. Do not boil.
  3. Combine: Reserve 1/4 cup of the coconut sauce for serving. Pour the rest over the hot sticky rice. Mix well, cover, and let sit for 15 minutes to absorb flavors.
  4. Serve: Place sticky rice on a plate with sliced mango alongside. Drizzle with reserved coconut sauce.
  5. Garnish: Sprinkle toasted sesame seeds or mung beans on top before serving.

Tips & Variations

  • Use ripe, sweet mangoes like Nam Dok Mai or Ataulfo for best results.
  • Do not boil the coconut milk; it should just be warmed to keep it smooth.
  • For extra fragrance, add a pandan leaf to the coconut sauce while heating.
  • This dessert is best served fresh, slightly warm or at room temperature.

name: Panang Curry
recipe:
Panang Curry

Panang Curry is a rich and creamy Thai curry with a hint of sweetness and nuttiness. Made with Panang curry paste, coconut milk, and your choice of protein, it is slightly less spicy than red curry and often thickened with ground peanuts.

Ingredients (serves 3–4)

  • 400 g (14 oz) chicken, beef, pork, shrimp, or tofu
  • 2–3 tbsp Panang curry paste
  • 2 cups (480 ml) coconut milk
  • 2–3 kaffir lime leaves, torn
  • 1–2 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for vegetarian)
  • 1–2 tsp palm sugar (or brown sugar)
  • 2 tbsp ground peanuts (optional, for nutty flavor)
  • 1 tbsp vegetable oil
  • Fresh Thai basil or cilantro for garnish

Instructions

  1. Heat oil: In a pan or wok, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add Panang curry paste and sauté for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
  2. Add coconut milk: Pour in half of the coconut milk, stirring to combine with curry paste. Simmer 2–3 minutes.
  3. Add protein: Add your choice of chicken, beef, pork, shrimp, or tofu. Cook until nearly done.
  4. Add seasonings: Stir in fish sauce, palm sugar, and ground peanuts (if using). Mix well.
  5. Add remaining coconut milk: Pour in the rest of the coconut milk. Simmer gently for 5–10 minutes until meat is tender and sauce thickens.
  6. Finish: Add torn kaffir lime leaves and stir well.
  7. Serve: Garnish with Thai basil or cilantro. Serve hot with steamed jasmine rice.

Tips & Variations

  • Panang curry is usually less soupy than other Thai curries; keep sauce slightly thick.
  • Vegetarian version: Use tofu and soy sauce instead of meat and fish sauce.
  • Other vegetables such as bell peppers, carrots, or zucchini can be added.
  • For extra nuttiness, sprinkle with crushed roasted peanuts before serving.

name: Satay with Peanut Sauce
recipe:
Satay with Peanut Sauce

Satay is a Southeast Asian favorite: marinated, skewered, and grilled meat served with a rich, savory-sweet peanut sauce. This version uses chicken, but you can swap in tofu, beef, or prawns.

Ingredients (serves 4)

For the Satay

  • 700 g (1.5 lb) boneless chicken thighs or breast, cut into thin strips
  • 12–16 bamboo skewers (soaked in water 30 minutes)

Satay Marinade

  • 2 tbsp soy sauce
  • 1 tbsp fish sauce (optional)
  • 2 tbsp brown sugar or palm sugar
  • 2 tbsp neutral oil
  • 1 tbsp curry powder (or 1–2 tsp red curry paste)
  • 1 tsp ground coriander
  • 1 tsp ground cumin
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 tsp grated ginger
  • 1 tbsp lime juice

Peanut Sauce

  • 1/2 cup creamy peanut butter
  • 3/4 cup coconut milk (or water for lighter)
  • 1–2 tbsp red curry paste (or 1 tsp chili-garlic sauce)
  • 1–2 tbsp soy sauce
  • 1–2 tbsp brown sugar or palm sugar
  • 1–2 tbsp lime juice
  • 1 tsp rice vinegar (optional)
  • 2 tsp fish sauce (optional)
  • Warm water as needed to thin

To Serve

  • Cucumber slices, red onion, fresh coriander
  • Lime wedges
  • Steamed jasmine rice or rice cakes

Instructions

  1. Marinate: In a bowl, whisk all marinade ingredients. Add chicken strips, coat well, and marinate 30 minutes (up to 8 hours).
  2. Skewer: Thread chicken onto soaked skewers in a serpentine fashion.
  3. Make peanut sauce: In a small saucepan, combine peanut butter and coconut milk over low heat. Stir in curry paste, soy, sugar, lime juice, and optional fish sauce/vinegar. Simmer gently 2–3 minutes, thinning with warm water to a pourable consistency. Taste and balance salty-sour-sweet-heat.
  4. Grill/Cook: Preheat grill, grill pan, or broiler to high. Lightly oil grates. Cook skewers 2–3 minutes per side (5–7 minutes total) until cooked through and lightly charred.
  5. Serve: Rest 2 minutes. Plate with peanut sauce, cucumber, herbs, and lime. Serve with rice.

Tips & Variations

  • Tofu satay: Use extra-firm tofu (pressed), marinate gently, and grill until crisp edges form.
  • Beef/prawn: Thin-sliced beef cooks quickly; prawns need only 1–2 minutes per side.
  • Make-ahead: Peanut sauce keeps 1 week refrigerated. Rewarm with a splash of water.
